docs.title: Welcome to BrahmWiki
docs.text:
A comprehensive, open-source collection of libraries for ESP32, ATmega328P, and ATmega2560 microcontrollers.

BrahmWiki is a centralized resource for high-quality, reusable code for your embedded systems projects. Whether you're a hobbyist, a student, or a professional, you'll find a growing collection of libraries to help you get your projects up and running faster.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
Getting started with BrahmWiki is easy. You can either clone this repository to your local machine or fork it to your own GitHub account to start contributing.

  • Browse the Libraries: Use the navigation on the left to explore the available libraries.
  • Check the Examples: Each library comes with examples for each supported platform.
  • Contribute: Have a library you'd like to share? We'd love to have you contribute!

docs.title: Library Categories
docs.text:
• Actuators

    Libraries for controlling motors, servos, and other output devices.

  • Communication

    Libraries for I2C, UART, Wi-Fi, and other communication protocols.

  • Sensors

    Libraries for reading data from a wide variety of sensors.

docs.title: Adding a New Library
docs.text:
Adding a new library to BrahmWiki is simple. Just follow these steps:

  1. Create a new directory for your library inside the appropriate category in the lib/ directory (e.g., lib/sensors/new_sensor).
  2. Add your source code to a src/ directory inside your new library's folder.
  3. Add examples for each supported platform to an examples/ directory.
  4. Create a README.md file in your library's directory with documentation, wiring diagrams, and API references. You can use lib/sensors/sensor_template/README.md as a starting point.

Once you've created your library, submit a pull request, and we'll review it for inclusion in the collection.

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Wire the sensor according to your microcontroller
  2. Include the library header in your project
  3. Initialize the sensor
  4. Read sensor data

docs.title: sensor_init(pin)
docs.text:
Initialize sensor on specified pin.

Parameters: - pin: GPIO pin number for data line

Returns: 0 on success, -1 on error

docs.title: sensor_read_temp()
docs.text:
Read temperature value from sensor.

Returns: Temperature in Celsius as float

docs.title: 🔍 Example Usage
docs.text: See the examples section for complete implementation examples for each supported microcontroller.

docs.title: 📖 Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• No sensor detected: Check wiring and pull-up resistor
  • Incorrect readings: Verify power supply voltage
  • Communication errors: Check data line connection

This section contains detailed information and setup guides for the microcontrollers supported by the BrahmWiki library collection.

Use the navigation on the left to select a microcontroller and view its documentation.

docs.title: ATmega2560 Setup Guide
docs.text: 8-bit AVR microcontroller with more I/O

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Specification Details Architecture 8-bit AVR Operating Voltage 5V GPIO Pins 86 Analog Inputs 16

docs.title: Arduino IDE Setup
docs.text:
1. Install Arduino IDE
  2. Select Arduino Uno (ATmega328P) or Arduino Mega (ATmega2560)
  3. Connect via USB and select correct COM port

docs.title: Atmel Studio Setup
docs.text:
1. Download and install Atmel Studio
  2. Create new GCC C Executable Project
  3. Select ATmega2560 as target device
  4. Configure programmer (AVRISP, USBasp, etc.)

docs.title: ESP32 Setup Guide
docs.text: Dual-core 32-bit MCU with Wi-Fi & Bluetooth

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Specification Details Architecture 32-bit Xtensa Operating Voltage 3.3V GPIO Pins 34 Analog Inputs 18

docs.title: Arduino IDE Setup
docs.text:
1. Install Arduino IDE 2.0 or later
  2. Add ESP32 board manager URL: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/espressif/arduino-esp32/gh-pages/package_esp32_index.json
  3. Install ESP32 board package via Board Manager
  4. Select your ESP32 board from Tools > Board menu

docs.title: PlatformIO Setup
docs.text:
[env:esp32dev]
platform = espressif32
board = esp32dev
framework = arduino
